Command browse_website returned: Answer gathered from website: Machu Picchu is an ancient Inca citadel located in the Andes Mountains of Peru. It was built in the 15th century and was abandoned during the Spanish conquest. The site was rediscovered in 1911 by Hiram Bingham and has since become a popular tourist destination and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It is known for its impressive architecture, stunning natural surroundings, and the fact that it was built on major fault zones. The site features an urban and agricultural sector, with temples, warehouses, and a residential district. Machu Picchu was constructed as an estate for the Inca emperor Pachacuti and is believed to have been a religious and political center. The Incas built the estate around 1450 but abandoned it a century later. Today, Machu Picchu is a popular tourist destination, visited by thousands of tourists each year.

Command browse_website returned: Answer gathered from website: The Inca Empire was a pre-Columbian civilization that existed in South America from the early 13th century until the Spanish conquest in the 16th century. It was the largest empire in pre-Columbian America, centered in the Andean Mountains, and known for its monumental architecture, extensive road network, finely-woven textiles, use of knotted strings for record keeping and communication, agricultural innovations, and unique system of exchange based on reciprocity. The empire was organized into a central government with the Inca at its head and four provincial governments with strong leaders. The Inca society was linguistically diverse, with Quechua being the most important language. The Inca religion was polytheistic and centered around the worship of nature deities. The empire was eventually conquered by the Spanish, leading to the downfall of the Inca civilization.

Command browse_website returned: Answer gathered from website: The Quechua language is a family of indigenous languages spoken primarily in the Andes region of South America, including Peru, Bolivia, Ecuador, Colombia, and Chile. It is the most widely spoken pre-Columbian language family of the Americas, with an estimated 8-10 million speakers as of 2004. Quechua was the main language family of the Inca Empire and is still widely spoken today, being the co-official language of many regions and the second most spoken language family in Peru. The language has been recognized as an official language in Peru, Ecuador, and Bolivia. The text provides additional information on the grammar, dialects, and cultural significance of the Quechua language.

Command browse_website returned: Answer gathered from website: The text mentions several dialects of the Quechua language, including Cusco Quechua, North Bolivian Quechua, South Bolivian Quechua, Ecuadorian Kichwa, Southern Quechua (IIC) dialect, Central Quechua, Yaru Quechua, Huanuco Quechua, Ayacucho Quechua, Huallaga Quechua, Northern Kichwa, Northern Peruvian Quechua, Ancash Quechua, and Wanka Quechua. The dialects differ in pronunciation, vocabulary, and grammar.
